sources.title: Mr. Wong, Detective
sources.description: Title: Mr. Wong, Detective Summary: When a chemical manufacturer is killed after asking detective James Wong to help him, Wong investigates this and two subsequent murders. He uncovers a international spy ring hoping to steal... Directed by: William Nigh Actors: Boris Karloff, Grant Withers, Maxine Jennings Production Company: Monogram Pictures Release Date: 5 October 1938 (USA) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 When a chemical manufacturer is killed after asking detective James Wong to help him, Wong investigates this and two subsequent murders. He uncovers a international spy ring hoping to steal the formula for a poison gas being developed by the first victim's company.

sources.title: Mr. Wong, Detective (1938) | Colorized Public Domain Mystery Film with Boris Karloff & Grant Withers
sources.description:
Mr. Wong, Detective (1938) is a classic American mystery film directed by William Nigh and produced by Monogram Pictures. This colorized and digitally restored edition by Colorized Public Domain revives one of the earliest Hollywood detective films to blend Eastern intelligence with Western crime-solving. Featuring the legendary Boris Karloff in a rare non-horror role, the film introduced audiences to the calm, methodical, and brilliant Chinese-American sleuth James Lee Wong â€” a character adapted from Hugh Wileyâ€™s Collierâ€™s magazine stories. Through careful restoration and color enhancement, this edition brings new depth to the shadows and suspense of 1930s mystery cinema, making it engaging for modern viewers in the United States, Europe, and worldwide.

Plot Summary:
The film opens in San Francisco, where the sudden death of a chemical company president, Simon Dayton, shocks the city. Although it first appears to be a heart attack, evidence quickly suggests murder. Mr. Wong, a refined and highly intelligent detective with deep knowledge of science and criminology, is called in to assist. Using his analytical skills and quiet observation, Wong uncovers a web of industrial espionage and betrayal surrounding a new secret chemical formula. When more deaths occur, the investigation becomes a race against time. Assisted by the brash but good-hearted police captain Street, Wong follows the clues through laboratories, shipping docks, and high-society offices. The tension rises as the murdererâ€™s plan unfolds, culminating in a gripping confrontation that proves intelligence and composure can outmatch violence and greed.

Cast and Crew:
â€¢ Director: William Nigh
â€¢ Producer: Scott R. Dunlap
â€¢ Screenplay: Houston Branch
â€¢ Based on: Stories by Hugh Wiley
â€¢ Cinematography: Harry Neumann
â€¢ Studio: Monogram Pictures
Starring:
â€¢ Boris Karloff as James Lee Wong
â€¢ Grant Withers as Captain Street
â€¢ Maxine Jennings as Myra Ross
â€¢ Evelyn Brent as Olga Goluboff
â€¢ Lucien Prival as Anton Mohl
â€¢ William Gould as Simon Dayton
â€¢ John Hamilton as Theodore Meisle
â€¢ Wilbur Mack as Devlin
â€¢ Lee Tung Foo as Willie

Film Significance:
Mr. Wong, Detective stands as a milestone in early American detective cinema, blending mystery, science, and social intrigue. Boris Karloffâ€™s portrayal of James Lee Wong marked a notable shift from his horror roles to an intelligent, culturally respectful character inspired by classic pulp fiction detectives. The filmâ€™s success led to five sequels, forming one of Monogram Picturesâ€™ most popular serial franchises. It showcased the studioâ€™s ability to create suspenseful, low-budget features that competed with major studio mysteries of the era. The storyâ€™s tone â€” methodical, restrained, and atmospheric â€” appealed to audiences who enjoyed deduction-based storytelling, bridging the gap between American mystery traditions and the logical precision popularized in British detective fiction.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like Mr. Wong, Detective remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. This process respects the original film while providing a new layer of appreciation for todayâ€™s viewers.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1938 release was filmed in black and white, typical of Monogram Picturesâ€™ limited budgets. Through digital colorization, this edition revitalizes the moody atmosphere of its San Francisco setting, adding depth to shadows and visual contrast that highlight the mysteryâ€™s tension. The restored version offers crisp detail, balanced tones, and enhanced clarity for todayâ€™s large-screen TV audiences â€” who form nearly half of all modern YouTube viewers. By restoring the filmâ€™s noir-like lighting and expressive performances, this colorized edition makes early detective storytelling more immersive for modern audiences who appreciate both classic style and modern presentation quality.

sources.title: Mr. Wong Detective (1938) BORIS KARLOFF
sources.description:
Stars: Boris Karloff, Grant Withers, Maxine Jennings
Director: William Nigh

When a chemical manufacturer is killed after asking detective James Wong to help him, Wong investigates this and two subsequent murders. He uncovers a international spy ring hoping to steal the formula for a poison gas being developed by the first victim's company.
